Ok any republican takers? Cause from my liberal view, I see no downside whatsoever to making all drugs legal and having them be sold by the government, and made by the government. 
 
 Isn't that infringe on our right of freedom? Cause my entire view on life is in my signature, so as long as it doesn’t effect anybody in ways they don't like, why can't we do it (do drugs of course)? 
 
 The Pros of government owned, drug selling-
 
 Gangs will no longer be able to afford the guns they used to buy through drug money, government prices will be lower then drug-dealers and people will know the government’s stuff is pure. 
 
 the money got through selling drugs could be used to lower taxes and increase funding.
 
 Kids will no longer be tempted to do drugs based on poor information, with the whole stigma of selling, buying and doing drugs gone, kids will make informed decisions based on information that isn't completely ridiculous. And if we do like other legal drugs, kids can only buy them at a certain age, and even then, warnings are printed on the label telling of the risks. 
 
 it would reduce funding for terrorism. 
 
 it will lower suicide rates because now psychologists can prescribe drugs to treat serious mental illness that can be administered from the home, and are very cheap.
 
 legalizing drugs will eventually lead to safer more user-friendly ways to get high. Eliminating the addictive, harmful drugs currently on the streets. 
 
 
 
 Cons- Tell me some my republican forum-mates

 We have already discussed your signature. Do you really want to base your entire life's philosophy on a logical fallacy.

Who me?
 
 Toxey..Me, who?

 
 Well, you changed your signature I see. To something even worse than the last time. You do realize that saying "there are no absolutes" is an absolute.
I started a thread for that, its in...pholpsohy, go thier to fight it.

hehe, the only problem i can see is all the programs you democrats to help the poor/lazy, with legal drugs a person can totally jack up their systems then force the taxpayers to pay them cause they are "disabled"
 
 i personally have no problem with folks blowing their own minds, as long as i dont have to pay for it later, i propose a system where you sign off on all support systems, welfare, social security, disability, and you also take full responsibility for the destruction of your body/mind to prevent lawsuits later on
 
 
 though when you say that it would prevent underage use i laugh, i live in a rural area, and the only thing to do around here on friday night is drink yourself silly, huge high school parties go on and the police rarely know where
 
 and also, the addictive effects will still be there, so more druggies will be stealing to support their habits, even a low price of drugs will not change this
 
 and who will it hurt but yourself, your family and friends, the relationships you will break for your addiction (and yes, you get addicted enough then nothing matters but the drugs) casual use, if not contained by laws, will become major addiction

Ok any republican takers? Cause from my liberal view, I see no downside whatsoever to making all drugs legal and having them be sold by the government, and made by the government. 
 
 
 It is not the job of our government's to "make drugs", nor sell them. They may govern the distribution, but they should not "sell" them. Take Pennsylvania for example...state liquor stores. While the employee who sits at the counter is technically a (state) government employee, he is a merchant. The liquor is still sold by the company that makes it. If it were done that way, I would have no problem with it. They purchase it initially, tax the hell out of it, and sell it to the population. Then, the governement would not be responsible for any deaths caused by the product. So long as they follow the prescribed laws concerning the distribution of the drug that is...
 
 
Isn't that infringe on our right of freedom? Cause my entire view on life is in my signature, so as long as it doesn't effect anybody in ways they don't like, why can't we do it (do drugs of course)? 
 
 
 Do speed limits infringe your right to freedom? Don't laws that say you must be 21 to drink alcohol infringe on the freedom of people under 21? Laws are made to account for the greatest benefit and safety of a society. The freedom argument is kinda out there. What kind of drugs are you speaking of in the first place? Marijuana...ok, no problem...I support the decriminalization of marijuana. Cocaine...ok, regular cocaine...fine. Crack...not a chance. Meth...no way. PCP...you must be joking. I think that all drugs should be taken on an individual basis...as they do with alcohol and tobacco.
 
 
Gangs will no longer be able to afford the guns they used to buy through drug money, government prices will be lower then drug-dealers and people will know the government's stuff is pure.
 
 
 You think gangs just sell drugs to buy guns? emoticon_rolleyes And since the government should not be selling it in the first place, it will not be their prices. But I would bet that with government tax, and controlled distribution, it would be more expensive than on the street, or at least the same price. 
 
 
Kids will no longer be tempted to do drugs based on poor information, with the whole stigma of selling, buying and doing drugs gone, kids will make informed decisions based on information that isn't completely ridiculous. 
 
 
 Like with tobacco and alcohol? Please. Kids will do them anyway, most kids don't make informed decisions about what to have for lunch...let alone what they smoke or drink. 
 
 
it would reduce funding for terrorism.
 
 
 Huh? You think that some Mexican marijuana farmer is giving his proceeds to Bin Laden? Some South American coca grower is donating his earnings to Hamas? Even the poppy farmers in the middle east are not funding terrorists, they are keeping their money, and getting rich in the process. Growing opium in the middle east is a legitimate business, just like growing corn is in the mid west. 
 
 
it will lower suicide rates because now psychologists can prescribe drugs to treat serious mental illness that can be administered from the home, and are very cheap.
 
 
 Psychologists do not prescribe drugs. Psychiatrists prescribe drugs. We already have many drugs to treat serious mental illness, which can be taken in the home. Many of them are available free at mental health clinics. While marijuana tends to help some people relax and relieve anxiety, it can sometimes have the opposite effect. And many of the illegal street drugs you are thinking of have little use in mental health cases. Some are great pain killers (opium, heroin), others are good for relieving nausea, stimulating appetite, and reducing the effects and pain of narrow angle glaucoma (marijuana), some to act as anesthetic agents (cocaine) etc... Few illegal street drugs would find any meaningful use in psychiatry. 
 
 
legalizing drugs will eventually lead to safer more user-friendly ways to get high. Eliminating the addictive, harmful drugs currently on the streets. 
 
 
 I don't get this one at all? What is a safer, more user friendly way to get high? You make it sound as if it is approved by the FDA it is a safe drug. There are no such things as completely safe drugs. And what about the harmful, addictive drugs approved for use by the FDA? Many drugs that we take every day can have serious harmful or even fatal effects. Many can be abused. 
 
 Do you know the real reason that street drugs are illegal in the first place?

For one, I enjoy that you think all those opposed to you are Republicans. That's a pretty narrow-minded assumption.
 
 
Kids will no longer be tempted to do drugs based on poor information, with the whole stigma of selling, buying and doing drugs gone, kids will make informed decisions based on information that isn't completely ridiculous. And if we do like other legal drugs, kids can only buy them at a certain age, and even then, warnings are printed on the label telling of the risks. 

 
 This is pretty absurd. Go give the common high school drug user a sheet with factual information about drugs, and I can promise you that they are not going to be impressed. Most states require health classes and refresher courses that already drill into these kids' heads the truths about drugs.
 
 And even those who do them without knowing the truths about them...?
 
 Ask any one of those drug users why they do drugs, and 95% of the time the answer will be because "they feel good", or something to that extent. No amazing new education about drugs is going to get kids to stop doing it for that reason. Look at cigarettes. They have warning labels all over them, and they're the most common drug out there. Why? Because they are legal.
 
 And just what we need to do is legalize date-rape drugs, right? Because those are of course something that the majority of users use for themselves.

To start off, the FDA has approved some nasty drugs out there, while banning things like marajuana. So we obvioulsy can't rely on them to decide what's safe. We should be making these choices, but since we expect the government to do it, we wait for them to, trust them, then argue them. They leave caffiene on the market, along with alcohol, and perscribe ritalin (don't get me started there). yeah safe, whatever.
 
 Personally I don't want to be on the road if a heroin addict can't tell the difference between a red and green street light. 
 
 Either they should legalize or illegalize them all. One or the other. that's the only thing that would make sense.
 
 Now we can't illegalize them all, because some are actually used for medication and patients would die without them.
 
 So I guess we're back to where we started.

Contrary to reducing crime, I happen to believe that legalizing drugs will INCREASE it. There will be millions of more addicts every year. And sold legally the prices will be cheaper, raking in even more, and since it's so cheap they can buy a lot of it. So man, many will die from overdosing, and the others that don't will have used so much they'll need more and more to get a high. And can many people support a long running increasing drug addiction? I don't think so. So they'll turn to stealing, or fraud, to get the money they need.

Until recently, I didn't really see any problems with legalising drugs. But after I was made the intended car jacking victim of a guy who had a passion for drugs, I have come to realise that the danger in drug taking reaches far beyond the addict.
 
 The guy was virtually unstoppable. He could recklessly drive and crash a car, but even with injury, was absolutely focussed when it came to acquiring a new vehicle, whatever it took. He was motivated by the fact he was being chased by an army of gun wielding maniacs (which turned out to be a figment of his amphetamine mixed imagination). 
 
 Now I realise making something illegal, doesn't necessarily prevent it from happening, but I don't think that any society can afford to send a message to it's citizens saying that inducing your mind into a completely uncontrollable state is acceptable behaviour (If it was in the privacy of your own cell, I might be inclined to agree). By legalising something, we are in effect saying that it's okay to try it... and unfortunately people are dangerously unpredictable when they take SOME illicit drugs and can't handle the result. The fact is, they are potentially harming other people, not just themselves.
 
 Perhaps we need to clarify which drugs we are considering legalising?

Greetings to Draconis and All:
 
 Draconis wrote << Ok any republican takers? Cause from my liberal view, I see no downside whatsoever to making all drugs legal and having them be sold by the government, and made by the government. 
 
 Terral's reply << Some of what you are saying here represents the reason I could never be a liberal Democrat, even though the Republicans are currently out to lunch on many domestic issues today. Our government is a poor vehicle through which to dispense anything, much less our vital drug medications. Anything that can be done in the private sector can also be done by the government, at twice or three times the cost. Our current high prices on many drugs are due to mountains of red tape associated with the FDA, and government officials bending over for the medical lobby in Washington. But since Americans allow the wishes special interest groups to supersede the needs of the people, then we are getting what we deserve. 
 
 Draconis << Isn't that infringe on our right of freedom? Cause my entire view on life is in my signature, so as long as it doesn't effect anybody in ways they don't like, why can't we do it (do drugs of course)? 
 
 Terral's reply << What about all the people who earn an honest living marketing pharmaceuticals in this country? Your idea includes displacing tens of thousands of people from a free market enterprise so that you can find yourself in a communist/socialist system. Did we learn anything from the fall of the USSR or not? 
 
 Draconis << The Pros of government owned, drug selling-Gangs will no longer be able to afford the guns they used to buy through drug money, government prices will be lower then drug-dealers and people will know the government's stuff is pure. 
 
 Terral's reply << Criminals have guns already, and they can steal them when they cannot afford them. BTW, placing more laws on law abiding citizens does not affect criminals at all. They break all the existing laws already. You are advocating an even larger Government with more control over individuals in this country. That is the reason for the creation of the underground drug culture that we have today. Has anyone noticed that more and more cigarettes are being sold by the growing underground market? When taxes are too high, Americans find ways to lower them. In the same way, your idea to allow Government to control our medicines would create a new generation of underground kingpins who are more than happy to reap the rewards. What would you do when they raise taxes on your meds like they are with cigarettes and gasoline? 
 
 Draconis << the money got through selling drugs could be used to lower taxes and increase funding.
 
 Terra's reply << No sir. That money would be spent in unemployment compensation for all of those people you put out of work, and hiring the three government people it would then take to replace them. Look at what they are doing with Social Security, as a 'go to' slush fund resource. 
 
 This is a bit off topic, but, are you aware that the Federal Reserve is a private company with a chairman and shareholders? Are you also aware that the fifth plank of the Communist Manifesto includes language pertaining to a Central Bank (source: http://www.geocities.com/christianpatriot2001/communist.html ). Our forefathers never intended for us to have one. When they raise interest rates, where do you suppose all of that money goes? I can tell you where: into the pockets of families like Rothschild, Warburg and other European International Bankers. Families like the J.P. Morgan's (started the Panic of 1907) and the Rockefeller's were given seats in the early 1910's. The Federal Reserve Act was passed in November of 1913, after the same bill failed in 1910 under the Paul Warfield name (source: None Dare Call It Conspiracy; Gary Allen; see here http://www.hiddenmysteries.com/item300/item343.html ). 
 
 Our government is fully aware that the Treasury no longer has the power to print money. That most important task was given to this band of Euro speculators who run the Federal Reserve (what a sham). And you want those same government officials, who allow foreigners to govern our monetary system, to also manage our medications? I do not believe that the majority of your liberal Democrat buddies are standing with you on this one.
 
 Draconis << Kids will no longer be tempted to do drugs based on poor information, with the whole stigma of selling, buying and doing drugs gone, kids will make informed decisions based on information that isn't completely ridiculous. And if we do like other legal drugs, kids can only buy them at a certain age, and even then, warnings are printed on the label telling of the risks. 
 
 Terral's reply << Whether your government or private enterprise controls the flow of medicine to this country, some children will continue to sniff glue, Rightguard, gasoline, and anything else they can find. And, in case you are unaware, people grow weed in closed rooms under lights, clay pots, backyards, over fences and just about anywhere possible. Even if the government sold pot, people can grow better strains on their own for free. 
 
 Draconis << it would reduce funding for terrorism. 
 
 Terral's reply << How much funding do you believe that terrorism requires? Terrorists can steal whatever resources they need. Also, remember that the main components of the Oklahoma City bombing were fertilizer and fuel oil (source: http://www.holology.com/mcveigh.html ). The right amount of propane gas could have the same result. And just how much did those Saudi terrorists spend preparing for 9/11? Not much. Therefore, funding has little to do with the topic of terrorism. 
 
 Draconis << it will lower suicide rates because now psychologists can prescribe drugs to treat serious mental illness that can be administered from the home, and are very cheap.
 
 Terral's reply << We would be far ahead today if we allowed private companies to handle our Social Security. Letting Government control the healthcare system would send prices off the charts. And people like myself would not be allowed to earn money by marketing medications. (two of my sites: www.gmedonline.com and www.canadamedsstore.com ).
 
 Draconis << legalizing drugs will eventually lead to safer more user-friendly ways to get high. Eliminating the addictive, harmful drugs currently on the streets. 
 
 Terral's reply << What you are describing is available today in the form of Prozac, Valium, etc.. The illegal trafficking of drugs on American streets is not the result of supply side economics. It will continue to thrive so long as the demand for these drugs exists. Your larger government need not legalize the sale of pot to curb the illegal importation and sales in this country. They have only to allow citizens to grow for their own use. After all, we can find a thousand better uses for our money, than the housing, feeding, clothing and medicating of potheads of this country. 
 
 God bless,
 
 Terral

While weed might be "safe" enough to be legalized and taxed heavily (it seems to work fine in Holland), harder drugs are too destructive, and have too much impact on a person's ability to act in everyday society to really be legalized.
 
 And simply because it is legal, wont make things like cocaine free. People will still commit crimes to buy them.
 On the contrary, it might even increase in price compared to current levels, since it would undoubtedly be taxed.
 
 
 As for republican views.. Im a socialist, and I still oppose legalized drugs. So eh

No drugs made legal........ohhhhhhh noooooo emoticon_xdonno Burn out our brains cells it will (think of Yoda). Besides.............drink BOOZE......I've got stock and I am stocked up too.
 
 Seriously.......the thought of a government actually controling and distributing drugs to the public......mind altering drugs......no thanks. THAT would be WAY to 1984-ish, way to Solent Green.

 I am going to sum up your plan in 1 phrase: the dumbest idea I have ever heard of. I am Republican. That plan will never go into practice, no matter who becomes President.
 "Isn't that infringe on our right of freedom? Cause my entire view on life is in my signature, so as long as it doesn't effect anybody in ways they don't like, why can't we do it (do drugs of course)? "
 The main thing is it will effect people. People will get high and drive, thus killing people. People will overdose and the government will pay the burden of their hospital bills (in some cases with poor people). It effects everyone, not just the person who decides to do drugs.  Why do you think there will be fewer people in prison? If it was legal, you could walk around high and it would be ok. You would have people messed up on drugs committing so many more crimes. There wouldn't be as many people in jail for illegally selling drugs, however there would be a lot more people in jail for crimes they committed while they were under the influence of drugs. Why should the government be obligated to pay for the rehab of someone who got addicted to drugs? That just puts more of a burden on tax-payers. We don't want to have to pay for some druggies rehab. Legalizing drugs will just create more problems than there already are.

 The reason why alcohol and tobacco deaths are so high is due to the fact that they are legal. It is not legal to snort cocaine or shoot up with heroin. Therefore, there are much less people out there doing LSD and PCP than people drinking or smoking cigarettes. Maybe legalizing marijuana, I could possibly see that, mainly because of the medicinal purposes. However, PCP, LSD, crack/cocaine, or anything else like that has no medical use.

Therefore, there are much less people out there doing LSD and PCP than people drinking or smoking cigarettes. Maybe legalizing marijuana, I could possibly see that, mainly because of the medicinal purposes. However, PCP, LSD, crack/cocaine, or anything else like that has no medical use.

 Here is what we can do out law booze. Make pot legal. Make stiffer penalty's 
 for harder drugs.

The reason why alcohol and tobacco deaths are so high is due to the fact that they are legal. It is not legal to snort cocaine or shoot up with heroin. Therefore, there are much less people out there doing LSD and PCP than people drinking or smoking cigarettes. Maybe legalizing marijuana, I could possibly see that, mainly because of the medicinal purposes. However, PCP, LSD, crack/cocaine, or anything else like that has no medical use.

 
 
 Well, that's what I was saying. I don't think all drugs should be legal!! I just think marijuana should be. Q. Is Marijuana Addictive?
 A. No, it is not [8]. Most users are moderate consumers who smoke it socially to relax. We now know that 10% of our population have "addictive personalities" and they are neither more nor less likely to overindulge in cannabis than in anything else. On a relative scale, marijuana is less habit forming than either sugar or chocolate but more so than anchovies. Sociologists report a general pattern of marijuana use that peaks in the early adult years, followed by a period of levelling off and then a gradual reduction in use [9]. Q. Does Marijuana Lead to Crime and/or Hard Drugs?
 A. No [11]. The only crime most marijuana users commit is that they use marijuana. And, while many people who abuse dangerous drugs also smoke marijuana, the old "stepping stone" theory is now discredited, since virtually all of them started out "using" legal drugs like sugar, coffee, cigarettes, alcohol, etc.Q. How Does Marijuana Affect Your Health?
 A. Smoking anything is not healthy, but marijuana is less dangerous than tobacco and people smoke less of it at a time. This health risk can be avoided by eating the plant instead of smoking it [13], or can be reduced by smoking smaller amounts of stronger marijuana. There is no proof that marijuana causes serious health or sexual problems [14] but, like alcohol, its use by children or adolescents is discouraged. Cannabis is a medicinal herb that has hundreds of proven, valuable theraputic uses - from stress reduction to glaucoma to asthma to cancer therapy, etc. 
 Blue emoticon_xgood

 Yes you are right I will agree with you all day long. emoticon_xhoho

You say that somehow when you're addicted to a drug, nothing matters but the drug. This is completely false in the case of weed. I've been a stoner for three years now, and I've yet to notice a decline in grades, or a significant change in my relationships with my family or friends. 
 When one is under the influence of marijuana, the feeling is nothing short of euphoria, but it is not one that would be more interesting than being with my friends. Even substances like "blubonic chronic" or "60/120" that almost give the user the feeling of not being real, of a blissful escape from reality, is not something I want to do alone. 
 Getting high is something I choose to do so I'm going to pay for it, that may mean having to get a job at this age, but I enjoy getting high with my friends. I'm a heavy smoker, two to three times a day, but only because I can. It's something that makes me creative and increases humor. A life of just hanging out with your friends, writing poetry, getting stoned, and being loved; how can this be a wasted life?

Why do you think there will be fewer people in prison? If it was legal, you could walk around high and it would be ok. You would have people messed up on drugs committing so many more crimes. There wouldn't be as many people in jail for illegally selling drugs, however there would be a lot more people in jail for crimes they committed while they were under the influence of drugs. Why should the government be obligated to pay for the rehab of someone who got addicted to drugs? That just puts more of a burden on tax-payers. We don't want to have to pay for some druggies rehab. Legalizing drugs will just create more problems than there already are.

 
 From what I understand 60% of the prison population is there because of a drug-related crime. If you de-criminalize drugs and treat it as the public health problem that it is, you would reduce the ridiculous prison population we have built up. 
 
 No one said you can "walk around high and it would be OK." Alcohol is legal, and in most places you aren't allowed in public while intoxicated (not Bourbon Street, of course). This statement is the same kind of mentality they had during the prohibition movement. They thought that prohibiting alcohol would reduce crime and it skyrocketed during prohibition because of the newly created black market for alcohol. Gangs got rich and powerful. The new gangs are the drug cartels. The only reason they exist is because the drug they make/sell is illegal. 
 
 People who want to do drugs will do them whether they are illegal or not (unless they are in prison, well, maybe even there). 
 
 
The reason why alcohol and tobacco deaths are so high is due to the fact that they are legal. It is not legal to snort cocaine or shoot up with heroin. Therefore, there are much less people out there doing LSD and PCP than people drinking or smoking cigarettes. Maybe legalizing marijuana, I could possibly see that, mainly because of the medicinal purposes. However, PCP, LSD, crack/cocaine, or anything else like that has no medical use.

 
 So many people die from alcohol because so many people use it. It is probably the oldest and definitely the most widely used mood-altering drug. 
 
 Cocaine is an anesthetic and was used as such for quite a while before it was outlawed.
 
 Heroin, same story.
 
 There are certain drugs that would be quite stupid to allow. Heroin, cocaine, and PCP are definitely on that list. Heroin isn't a party/social drug and it would be stupid to make it legal and available. This does not mean that a heroin user belongs in jail. Cocaine is pretty benign except for the fact that it is so strongly habit forming and will cause health detriments very quickly. PCP just messes your XXX up. 
 
 Now, LSD cannot be put in the same basket as these. LSD is almost something that everyone should try at least once. It is NOT habit forming at all and I've never heard of anyone that OD'd on it. I think the more people try LSD the more understanding of the world and other people they would experience. It opens your mind, plain and simple.
 
 After all that...
 
 Having a list of legal drugs and illegal drugs is what we have now. Moving a drug or two from one column to the other wouldn't really change much in the way of prison population and organized crime. The prison population reduction would come by de-criminalizing drug use/sale. Putting someone in the same prison cell as a rapist or murderer for selling a pound of weed is a crime in itself.

You say that somehow when you're addicted to a drug, nothing matters but the drug. This is completely false in the case of weed. I've been a stoner for three years now, and I've yet to notice a decline in grades, or a significant change in my relationships with my family or friends. 
 When one is under the influence of marijuana, the feeling is nothing short of euphoria, but it is not one that would be more interesting than being with my friends. Even substances like "blubonic chronic" or "60/120" that almost give the user the feeling of not being real, of a blissful escape from reality, is not something I want to do alone. 
 Getting high is something I choose to do so I'm going to pay for it, that may mean having to get a job at this age, but I enjoy getting high with my friends. I'm a heavy smoker, two to three times a day, but only because I can. It's something that makes me creative and increases humor. A life of just hanging out with your friends, writing poetry, getting stoned, and being loved; how can this be a wasted life?

 
 Smoking weed definitely makes you lazier. You tend to be ok with being bored and one's initiative for work is diminished. I wholly believe that weed should be legal, but that's it's one downside. It can turn you into a couch potato.

Smoking weed definitely makes you lazier. You tend to be ok with being bored and one's initiative for work is diminished. I wholly believe that weed should be legal, but that's it's one downside. It can turn you into a couch potato.

 
 Smoking weed only makes you lazier for things that require physical labor, but mentally, you seem to want to create things more. It gives further impetus to imaginative thoughts. So, if you're a writer or a scientist or a poet emoticon_smile then smoking weed can help you to be better at such things.
 like for example, i wrote this while i was high,
 I wish that I could hold you in my heart and take you to the places my mind dreams, soar with you under an onyx sky broken only by celestial wonders unnamable or kiss you in an ocean of petals so as to never forget how beautiful you are, and you would never forget how much i love you.
 A person can and most likely will be inspired while they are stoned. Poetically stoned.

From what I understand 60% of the prison population is there because of a drug-related crime. If you de-criminalize drugs and treat it as the public health problem that it is, you would reduce the ridiculous prison population we have built up.
 
 
 
 You're correct in assuming that we could reduce the prison population if we made drugs legal. But if we have to treat it as a health problem, then the US taxpayers' money is going to treat crack heads and people who abused drugs and commit crimes, rather than lock these people up and prevent them from committing more crimes. Homesless people and others who abuse drugs typically steal to get money to buy more drugs, which creates more crimes while we still have to pay for their "health problem". I don't favor legalizing drugs, but if we do, the US taxpayers' money should not, in any case, go towards paying for the health problems associated with someone's drug abuse. Also, health care will increase because people will have their insurance companies pay for their bad choices in life.
 
 
 
People who want to do drugs will do them whether they are illegal or not (unless they are in prison, well, maybe even there).
 
 
 
 That is a terrible reason to legalize drugs. People will murder others whether it is illegal or not, so why don't we legalize murder?
 
 
 
There are certain drugs that would be quite stupid to allow. Heroin, cocaine, and PCP are definitely on that list. Heroin isn't a party/social drug and it would be stupid to make it legal and available. This does not mean that a heroin user belongs in jail. Cocaine is pretty benign except for the fact that it is so strongly habit forming and will cause health detriments very quickly. PCP just messes your XXX up.
 
 
 
 If heroin shouldn't be legalized, then it will remain illegal. How should someone not be put in prison for blatantly violating the law?
 
 
 
 
Having a list of legal drugs and illegal drugs is what we have now. Moving a drug or two from one column to the other wouldn't really change much in the way of prison population and organized crime. The prison population reduction would come by de-criminalizing drug use/sale. Putting someone in the same prison cell as a rapist or murderer for selling a pound of weed is a crime in itself.

 
 
 With prison population reduction also comes an increase in healthcare costs, and more people relying on the government to treat their illnesses caused by their wrong choices in abusing drugs. It's a no win situation. We can either let drug users who are going to commit crimes (stealing to buy more drugs, etc) out of jail, only to commit more crimes and go back to jail, while also increasing healthcare costs, or we can have a high population of criminals in prison. I would feel much safer driving on the road knowing that a guy who does quaaludes is behind bars, rather than worry about what drug the guy behind me is on.

You're correct in assuming that we could reduce the prison population if we made drugs legal. But if we have to treat it as a health problem, then the US taxpayers' money is going to treat crack heads and people who abused drugs and commit crimes, rather than lock these people up and prevent them from committing more crimes. Homesless people and others who abuse drugs typically steal to get money to buy more drugs, which creates more crimes while we still have to pay for their "health problem". I don't favor legalizing drugs, but if we do, the US taxpayers' money should not, in any case, go towards paying for the health problems associated with someone's drug abuse. Also, health care will increase because people will have their insurance companies pay for their bad choices in life.
 
 
 That is a terrible reason to legalize drugs. People will murder others whether it is illegal or not, so why don't we legalize murder?
 
 If heroin shouldn't be legalized, then it will remain illegal. How should someone not be put in prison for blatantly violating the law?
 
 With prison population reduction also comes an increase in healthcare costs, and more people relying on the government to treat their illnesses caused by their wrong choices in abusing drugs. It's a no win situation. We can either let drug users who are going to commit crimes (stealing to buy more drugs, etc) out of jail, only to commit more crimes and go back to jail, while also increasing healthcare costs, or we can have a high population of criminals in prison. I would feel much safer driving on the road knowing that a guy who does quaaludes is behind bars, rather than worry about what drug the guy behind me is on.

 
 With legalizing drugs, and taxing them so that the street price would be the same as they are now the increased health care costs (minimal) would probably be easily covered. With the decreased costs in prison, each prisoner I bet costs $40 000 per year while incarcerated and often is less productive when released due to being a felon then he would otherwise be.
 
 With the accesability of drugs currently, if you want them you can get them. The person behind you probably has done them, is currently doing them or might be on them right now.
 
 For a quick breakdown of associates of mine
 
 at least 80% have tried weed
 40% cocaine
 40% steriods
 70% ectasy
 60% acid
 70% mushrooms
 
 As for health care costs associated with the above use, very minimal, two people have overdosed/ believed to have commited sucide.
 
 From the people above they have cost more to society with alcohol then the illegal drug use. Drunk driving, fights, and broken bones from doing drunken stupid things.
 
 Not that I am for unrestricted access to this drugs. especially the harder ones, but looking at Holland and the way drugs are treated their the costs to society seem to be less when legal but controlled then when illegal and uncontrolled.

One thing you failed to acknowledge was the correlation between people using mind-altering drugs and crime. Many people who use these drugs often get addicted, and will do anything to get more (i.e. crack whores and homesless who steal). By simply letting them do drugs without the fear of being reprimanded will drastically increase the street crimes committed.
 
 
 
 
With legalizing drugs, and taxing them so that the street price would be the same as they are now the increased health care costs (minimal) would probably be easily covered. With the decreased costs in prison, each prisoner I bet costs $40 000 per year while incarcerated and often is less productive when released due to being a felon then he would otherwise be.
 
 With the accesability of drugs currently, if you want them you can get them. The person behind you probably has done them, is currently doing them or might be on them right now.

 
 
 Like I said, if you want to murder someone, even though it's illegal, people will still do it. Stealing is illegal, but people still do it. Should we just give in and say, "Well everyone will do it no matter what the law is, so let's legalize everything"? What about those who go to detox centers or drug treatment centers? Who will pay for that if homeless people need help? I sure as hell am not dishing out any money to them.
 
 
 
 
For a quick breakdown of associates of mine
 
 at least 80% have tried weed
 40% cocaine
 40% steriods
 70% ectasy
 60% acid
 70% mushrooms
 
 As for health care costs associated with the above use, very minimal, two people have overdosed/ believed to have commited sucide.
 
 From the people above they have cost more to society with alcohol then the illegal drug use. Drunk driving, fights, and broken bones from doing drunken stupid things.
 
 Not that I am for unrestricted access to this drugs. especially the harder ones, but looking at Holland and the way drugs are treated their the costs to society seem to be less when legal but controlled then when illegal and uncontrolled.

 
 
 
 Once again, the phrase, "Everyone does it, why can't I?" is not a sensible or logical reason to legalize drugs. The government just can't give in to people because "everybody does it". What's next?

For associated crimes with the above group. Only possesion or traficking. None of then have commited property crimes.
 
 Overall I was addressing the costs to society from the drugs being illegal, to them being illegal. Much in the same way alcohol was illegal in the 1920's, and made legal. Comparing making drugs legal to murder is a very poor argument.

For associated crimes with the above group. Only possesion or traficking. None of then have commited property crimes.
 
 Overall I was addressing the costs to society from the drugs being illegal, to them being illegal. Much in the same way alcohol was illegal in the 1920's, and made legal. Comparing making drugs legal to murder is a very poor argument.

 
 
 Cocaine is very addicting. And people who get addicted to it often will go to the end of the world to get money to buy more, oftentimes resorting to stealing. Note the case of the crack whore. She will sell herself to get money to buy crack. Stealing is a property crime. Ever watch Cops? They pull people over all the time who are high on drugs, driving on the wrong side of the road, driving 5 MPH, or driving in reverse. Does that not put people in danger? 
 
 Now look at steroids. Ever heard of roid rage? People become violent. There was a case of a former Major League baseball player who beat his wife in a roid rage. Assault is not a property crime, but it is a crime directly associated with roid rage.
 
 I am not sure the effects of acid or mushrooms. But look at ecstacy. Whether it is legal or not, people will abuse it and use it to coerce girls into having sex with them. Making this legal will just make certain cases of rape involving ecstacy nearly unprosecutable. 
 
 How can you not see the possible crimes committed by people on these drugs?

The above group meant the people I know who have used drugs. Non have commited property crimes.
 
 Cocaine is addictive, but in general the level has alot to do with your personality, how often you do it overall much like alcohol. Crack, not having done it seems to be extremely addictive, which is why personally I would never touch it.
 
 Steriods, at the gym I go to at least 60% of the male members have used them. From what I have seen personally roid rage seems to be a fallacy. If you are violent before taking steriods, you are going to be violent with steriods. If you are nonviolent before steriods you are not going to be violent after steriods. I have a feeling the number of wife beating occur with men who are not on steriods.
 
 
 Ecstacy is a methampatamine, an upper if you will and makes people touchy feelly. It is not a date rape drug. Most males on it cant "perform", which is why viagra has become common when people take ecstacy. For the rape part of it I believe you are thinking of GHB and Rohipnol(sp). Both when combined with alcohol leave the woman in a passed out, or extremely drunk like state, which allows the man to rape them. Usually the woman did not willing take either, and yes this would be rape.
 
 Except for crack and heroin (of which I have no personall knowledge to make any statement) the other drugs listed by me seem to have no more of a determental effect on the users or society then overeating or alcohol.

The above group meant the people I know who have used drugs. Non have commited property crimes.

 
 
 Haha!! Since when did taking a poll at work have anything to do with homeless people committing crimes? Nobody at my works has gotten a DUI or killed person, and many of them drink. Is it safe for me to assume the same is true to for all? No. Just because you know a few people who do drugs and haven't committed property crimes shows me nothing. I have seen plenty of people in person and on TV who have in fact committed crimes while on drugs. The key is they have a job, and seem to not be addicted to the drugs. People without jobs who are addicted resort to stealing to get drug money. Do you not see that?
 
 
 
Steriods, at the gym I go to at least 60% of the male members have used them. From what I have seen personally roid rage seems to be a fallacy. If you are violent before taking steriods, you are going to be violent with steriods. If you are nonviolent before steriods you are not going to be violent after steriods. I have a feeling the number of wife beating occur with men who are not on steriods.

 
 
 I play baseball for a Division 1, top-25 baseball program. I know a lot of people, some who play ball and some who don't, that are on or have taken steroids. I have personally noticed a slight difference in their demeanor, but nothing major. Steroids also make people feel suicidal. I have read of numerous occasions where those on steroids have committed suicide. Once again, you give me some stats you took at a gym. That tells me nothing
 
 
 
Ecstacy is a methampatamine, an upper if you will and makes people touchy feelly. It is not a date rape drug. Most males on it cant "perform", which is why viagra has become common when people take ecstacy. For the rape part of it I believe you are thinking of GHB and Rohipnol(sp). Both when combined with alcohol leave the woman in a passed out, or extremely drunk like state, which allows the man to rape them. Usually the woman did not willing take either, and yes this would be rape.

 
 
 And since it makes people touchy feely, men have been known to slip it in women's drinks. How could that not occur?

I do see it, but I also see that with the criminalization of drugs, the prison population is soaring, due to from what I understand actual drug possession or selling of it. Criminal gangs get most of their money from drugs. People continue to use drugs even though they are illegal (like alcohol during the 20').
 
 By legalizing drugs and taxing them a few thing would probably happen
 
 1. Prison pop would decrease, saving the government money, which could be used for drug rehab programs.
 2. Extra revenue for the government by taxing the sale of drugs, which could be used for drug rehab programs.
 3. Eliminating the most profitable source of income for criminal gangs.
 4. Drug education will be more informative towards the effects of drugs, instead of "drugs are bad mmkay" which doesnt tell people anything.
 
 Will a few more people try drugs probably, will more crimes be commited probably not if rehab programs are more available and people are not afraid to use them for fear of being locked up. So that the homeless junkies will get treatment instead of being thrown on the street or locked up for a few months and still getting drugs in prison.

If ALL drugs are not legalized, people will still get thrown in jail for drug offences (related to cocaine, heroin, etc.).
 
 It is not likely that gangs will suddenly not have money and the prisons will be empty by just legalizing marijuana. Gangs will sell other drugs and get sent to jail for those crimes.
 
 However, it seems to be a general concensus that legalizing hard drugs is not a good idea.
 
 Therefor, "legalizing pot will decrease prison population and get rid of gangs" is not a valid arguement.
